  • Any supposed univocal core between God’s knowledge and ours would either:
    • Subordinate God to a shared conceptual scheme above him, or
    • Collapse God’s knowledge into a super-sized version of creaturely cognition.

  • Thus, Reformed analogical predication denies that there is a univocal concept that is first in order and then applied to God and creature alike; the order is reversed: what is first is God’s self-knowledge, which freely creates ectypal replicas suited to creatures.

  • Against equivocity (skeptical or nominalist):

  • Pure equivocity between divine and human predicates would entail that no inference from revelation to God is sound; “God is good” would convey no determinate, knowable content.

  • This would contradict:
    • The clarity of general and special revelation.
    • The covenantal character of God’s self-disclosure.
    • The Reformed assertion that Scripture gives true (though not exhaustive) knowledge of God.
  • Van Til insists that our knowledge is “thinking God’s thoughts after him”: not thinking thoughts unrelated to God’s thoughts (equivocity), nor thinking the very same thoughts as God (univocity), but thinking derivative replicas of those thoughts.

Thus, analogical predication is a middle way, but not a compromise; it is a principled alternative rooted in ontology and revelation: God’s thoughts are archetypal and self-originating; ours are ectypal and derivative, yet intentionally patterned by God so that there is real correspondence without identity.

Divine incomprehensibility and analogical predication

In a confessional Reformed and Van Tillian account, divine incomprehensibility is not merely quantitative but also qualitative.

  • Quantitative aspect: God cannot be comprehended because finite minds cannot exhaust the infinite object; we always know “in part.”
  • Qualitative aspect: God is not one being among others but the self-sufficient Creator; his mode of existence and knowing is categorically distinct from ours.

Analogical predication expresses precisely this duality:

  • Our predicates are true: when we say “God is wise,” we genuinely speak of the living God, and the content is not false or merely symbolic.
  • Our predicates are non-comprehensive and non-reciprocal: we never define or circumscribe God; the concept “wisdom” as we hold it does not exhaust what “wisdom” is in God, nor is it structurally identical with God’s internal act of knowing.

Van Til therefore insists that incomprehensibility is not an unfortunate limit but a logical consequence of God’s aseity and Lordship. If our knowledge were comprehensive or identical with God’s, then God would no longer be the self-interpretive Lord whose own knowledge is the ultimate reference point; he would share in an epistemic commonwealth with creatures. Analogy safeguards incomprehensibility while maintaining genuine, covenantal knowledge: God interprets himself for us in accommodated form, and that accommodated interpretation is the norm for all our theological language.

Divine simplicity and the unity of analogical predication

Divine simplicity is decisive for how analogical predication is construed in a Reformed framework rid of the analogia entis.

  • In God, attributes are identical with his essence and with one another. God’s goodness, wisdom, power, and life are not parts, properties added to a substrate, or differentiable formalities; they are the one simple act of God’s being and knowing.
  • Our language, however, is intrinsically discursive and multi-conceptual. We predicate “wise,” “good,” “just,” “infinite” as if they were distinct properties, because:
    • Our ectypal cognition is compositive and analytic.
    • Revelation unfolds God’s one simple being in multiple conceptual angles.

This creates a duality:

  • On the Creator side: The referent of all these varied predicates is one act, one simple God, whose self-knowledge is identical with his being.
  • On the creature side: The concepts by which we apprehend and articulate this one God are many, interrelated but distinct, progressively so in redemptive history.

Analogical predication is the fittingness of this duality: we speak truly of God’s wisdom, power, and love, yet we acknowledge that the distinctions we make in our concepts reflect the mode of ectypal knowledge, not a composition in God himself. Simplicity therefore intensifies analogicality:

  • It excludes any notion that our conceptual distinctions map isomorphically onto distinct “parts” in God.
  • It grounds the necessity of analogy: our many, partial perspectives correspond to the one simple reality as accommodated to us by God.

Summary relation among the loci

Putting the pieces together:

  • Univocity is rejected because it implies a shared genus or common concept bridging God and creature, which contradicts aseity, transcendence, and simplicity.
  • Equivocity is rejected because it nullifies revelation and makes true knowledge of God impossible.
  • Divine incomprehensibility is affirmed as a necessary implication of God’s infinite, self-contained perfection; we never know as God knows himself, but only as he freely makes himself known.
  • Divine simplicity requires that our multiple predicates about God be understood as multiple, finite, analogical ways of referring to one simple divine act of being and knowing, rather than as mirrors of real composition in God.

Therefore, in a Van Tillian yet confessionally Reformed framework, analogical predication names the creaturely, ectypal, accommodated way in which finite minds truly but non-comprehensively think God’s own thoughts after him, in correspondence without identity, thereby avoiding both univocity and equivocity while preserving divine incomprehensibility and simplicity.

top_exam_questions.question: Define positively what you mean by ‘knowledge by analogy’: what exactly is analogical in our knowledge of God (terms, concepts, mode of knowing, or something else?), and illustrate it with a concrete doctrinal example.
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal definition of analogical knowledge

“Knowledge by analogy” in classic Reformed usage means that our true knowledge of God is a **finite, creaturely replica** (ectype) of God’s own perfect self-knowledge (archetype), given by divine revelation and proportioned to our capacity. It is neither univocal (same mode and proportion of meaning as in God) nor purely equivocal (no real correspondence), but a **resemblant correspondence grounded in God’s voluntary self-communication**.

What is analogical is not merely some external “comparison,” but the entire relation between God’s self-knowledge and our knowledge of him:

- **Conceptually analogical.** The same predicate (e.g., “wise,” “good”) is applied to God and creatures with one basic meaning, but with a different ratio: in God it signifies an infinite, underived perfection identical with his essence; in us it signifies a finite, received habit or quality.
- **Ontologically analogical.** The perfection signified (say, wisdom) exists in God as simple, infinite being, and in creatures as a finite participation or effect of that divine perfection. God is wisdom; we are wise only by communication from him.
- **Noetically analogical (mode of knowing).** God knows himself immediately, comprehensively, and a se; we know him mediately, discursively, and from revelation. Our acts of knowing are dependent reproductions of the content and order of God’s own knowledge.
- **Linguistically analogical.** The same word is used of God and creatures, but the rules for its predication differ, controlled by the Creator–creature distinction and the whole analogy of faith.

Thus, in analogical knowledge, there is **real sameness of object and truth** (we truly know the real God) together with **ordered disproportion** between God’s way of having and knowing that truth and ours.

## Concrete doctrinal illustration: God’s goodness

Take the predicate **“God is good”** and compare it with **“this man is good.”**

### Ontological and conceptual structure

- When we say **“this man is good,”** we mean:
    - He possesses a created moral quality or habit that conforms (to some extent) to God’s law.
    - That quality is accidental to him: he can lose it, and it does not constitute his essence.
    - His goodness is finite, mixed with defect, and measured by a standard outside him.

- When we say **“God is good,”** in an analogical sense, we mean:
    - Goodness is not a separable quality in God but identical with his simple essence; God’s being and goodness are the same reality.
    - His goodness is infinite, underived, and the standard and measure of all creaturely goodness.
    - All creaturely goodness is an effect and reflection of his goodness, not a coordinate instance on the same scale.

Conceptually, the term “good” retains a core intelligible content: disposition toward what is fitting, perfective, and just. But:

- In God, that content is instantiated **infinitely and essentially**.
- In creatures, it is instantiated **finitely and accidentally**.

So the **same predicate** “good” is applied truly to both, but with a different metaphysical “mode”: in God, as subsisting perfection; in us, as participated and received.

### Mode of knowing

- God’s knowledge of his own goodness is **immediate and comprehensive**: he knows himself exhaustively and necessarily as the supreme good.
- Our knowledge of God’s goodness is:
    - Derived from his revelation in creation and Scripture.
    - Mediated by concepts formed first in the creaturely sphere (“goodness” as we experience it) and then elevated and corrected by God’s self-description.
    - Limited and ectypal: we never comprehend the manner or degree in which God is good, but we truly grasp that he is good in a way that grounds and exceeds all goodness in creatures.

In that sense, when we confess “God is good,” we are:

- Not speaking univocally, as if God and humans were simply instances of the same genus “goodness.”
- Not speaking equivocally, as if “good” had an unrelated sense in each case.
- Speaking analogically: **our creaturely concept of goodness, derived from God’s works and word, truly corresponds to the divine reality while acknowledging an infinite qualitative difference in the way that reality subsists in God and is known by him.**

In sum, knowledge by analogy means that in every true doctrine of God, our terms, concepts, and mode of knowing are divinely caused, proportionate creaturely replicas of God’s own perfect self-knowledge, so that our theology is simultaneously truthful and irreducibly creaturely.

top_exam_questions.question: According to the Westminster Confession and Belgic Confession, what kind of knowledge of God do all people have from general revelation, and how does that relate to your statement that ‘knowledge of God is only possible through special revelation’?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical and confessional setting

The Westminster Standards and the Belgic Confession both affirm a real, objective, and universally possessed knowledge of God from general revelation, while simultaneously denying that such knowledge is saving or sufficient for right worship. The apparent tension with the claim “knowledge of God is only possible through special revelation” is resolved by distinguishing kinds and ends of knowledge, not by denying the reality of general revelation.

## Confessional teaching on general revelation

Both confessions ascribe a rich content to general revelation.

- The **Belgic Confession** (article 2) speaks of the creation, preservation, and government of the world as a “most elegant book” in which “all creatures, great and small, are as so many characters” that “lead us to see clearly the invisible things of God, namely his eternal power and divinity.” This is not merely a bare awareness that “something” exists, but knowledge that is:
    
    - of the true God;
    - of his power and divinity;
    - sufficiently clear that humans are “without excuse” for their unbelief and idolatry (echoing Romans 1).

- The **Westminster Confession of Faith** (1.1) states that “the light of nature, and the works of creation and providence, do so far manifest the goodness, wisdom, and power of God, as to leave men inexcusable.” Again, this implies:
    
    - knowledge of God’s goodness, wisdom, and power;
    - such that failure to glorify and thank him is morally culpable.

Additionally, WCF 21.1 indicates that natural revelation teaches that there is a God who is “Lord and Sovereign over all,” to be feared, loved, praised, and obeyed. Thus, all people know enough of the true God to know that he ought to be worshiped and obeyed.

This knowledge is:
- objective (it is what God actually reveals of himself);
- ineradicable (suppressed but not annihilated by sin);
- morally binding (it grounds guilt and inexcusability).

## The limits of general revelation

Yet both confessions sharply restrict what general revelation can accomplish.

- WCF 1.1 immediately adds that general revelation is “not sufficient to give that knowledge of God, and of his will, which is necessary unto salvation.”
- WCF 10, 14, and 20 assume that saving faith, effectual calling, and Christian liberty presuppose the gospel as revealed in Scripture and applied by the Spirit.
- Belgic 2 goes on (in articles 3–7) to locate the knowledge of God’s saving will, his Christ, and the way of reconciliation exclusively in Scripture.

So the contrast is not between “knowledge vs. no knowledge” but between:
- a **natural, general, non-saving** knowledge of God as Creator, Lord, and Judge; and
- a **special, redemptive, saving** knowledge of God in Christ as revealed in the gospel.

## Clarifying the statement about “only possible through special revelation”

In a strict Reformed and confessional sense, the statement “knowledge of God is only possible through special revelation” is false if taken without qualification. The confessions clearly ascribe genuine knowledge of God to general revelation.

Properly qualified, the statement can be defended in at least two ways.

### First, by distinguishing kinds of knowledge

We must distinguish:

- **Natural knowledge of God**:
    
    - Grounded in God’s revelation in creation and providence.
    - Content: God’s existence, power, divinity, goodness, wisdom, and moral law (cf. Rom 1–2).
    - Effect under sin: always suppressed, always distorted into idolatry, but never erased; thus it yields guilt, not salvation.

- **Saving knowledge of God**:
    
    - Grounded in special revelation (culminating in Christ and inscripturated in Scripture).
    - Content: God’s gracious purpose in Christ, the way of redemption, the covenant of grace, the promises of the gospel.
    - Effect: by the Spirit, produces repentance and faith; restores the right use of the natural knowledge of God.

On this distinction, the statement should be reformulated: **saving knowledge of God is only possible through special revelation**. General revelation truly reveals God; only special revelation reveals him as Redeemer in Christ and is the means by which the Spirit grants saving knowledge.

### Second, by speaking of right, covenantal knowledge

Reformed theology sometimes uses “knowledge of God” in a more pregnant sense: not bare cognition, but covenantal, obedient, rightly ordered knowledge. In that sense:

- The unregenerate “know God” (Rom 1:21) yet “do not honor him as God or give thanks,” and “do not know God” rightly (cf. 1 Thess 4:5).
- Their knowledge is real but always perverted by rebellion; it is epistemically sufficient for condemnation but not for communion.

From that angle one may say:
- only through special revelation, and the regenerating work of the Spirit, does anyone come to “know God” in the reconciled, covenantal, filial sense envisioned in the gospel.

Again, the confessional line is preserved: general revelation gives true knowledge of God as Judge; special revelation (by the Spirit) gives true knowledge of God as Father in Christ.

## Synthesis

According to the Westminster and Belgic Confessions, all people possess a real, clear, and inexcusable knowledge of the true God from general revelation as Creator, Lord, and Judge, but only special revelation, applied by the Spirit, grants the saving, covenantal knowledge of God in Christ to which the gospel summons us.

top_exam_questions.question: Explain the archetypal/ectypal distinction as used by Reformed scholastics and define the principium essendi and principium cognoscendi (externum and internum). How do these principia ground analogical knowledge of God?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical and Conceptual Background

The archetypal/ectypal distinction and the principia language arise in post-Reformation scholasticism as a way to safeguard both divine incomprehensibility and the truth of theological knowledge. Reformed authors adapt earlier medieval themes but sharpen them under the pressure of the Creator–creature distinction and sola Scriptura.

These distinctions function together to answer two questions:

- What kind of knowledge does God have of himself, and what kind of knowledge can creatures have of God?
- What are the basic grounds and sources by which theology exists and is possible?

## Archetypal and Ectypal Knowledge

### Archetypal theology

“Archetypal” theology (theologia archetypa) is God’s own knowledge of himself.

- It is identical with God’s simple, infinite essence; it is not a habit or acquired science but God himself knowing himself.
- It is necessary, underived, comprehensive, and immediate; there is no gap between object, act, and content of knowing.
- It is incommunicable as such to creatures; a creature cannot be made omniscient or simple, and so cannot participate in archetypal theology.

Archetypal theology is therefore the self-knowledge of the triune God as he is in se, and it is the ultimate pattern and ground of all true theology, but never an object of direct creaturely possession.

### Ectypal theology

“Ectypal” theology (theologia ectypa) is theology “copied from” or “impressed by” the archetype into a creaturely mode.

- It is finite, discursive, habitus-like knowledge that God freely wills into existence.
- It is analogical: truly corresponding to God as he is, because patterned on the archetypal knowledge, yet proportioned to creaturely capacities.
- It appears in distinct modes:
    - In the **theologia unionis** (the knowledge of the incarnate Son according to his human mind).
    - In the **theologia visionis** (the immediate knowledge of the blessed in glory).
    - In the **theologia viatorum** (the pilgrim theology of believers on earth, mediated through revelation in word and sacrament).

The crucial point is that all creaturely theology, whether of Christ’s human mind, the saints in glory, or believers now, is ectypal: finite, receptive, and derivative, yet ordered to and conformed to the archetypal knowledge of God.

## The Principia of Theology

Reformed scholastics analyze theology in terms of its “principles” or foundations.

### Principium essendi

The **principium essendi** is the principle of being of theology: that which makes theology possible in reality.

- It is God himself, the triune Lord, as he exists and knows himself.
- Because God alone is self-existent and self-knowing, he is the ontological ground of all theology; apart from his being and his archetypal knowledge, neither revelation nor theology could exist.
- All ectypal knowledge presupposes that God is and that God knows; theology is possible only because God is the principium essendi of it.

Thus, the principium essendi is not a source that we consult but the metaphysical reality in virtue of which there can even be something called “knowledge of God.”

### Principium cognoscendi externum

The **principium cognoscendi externum** is the external principle of knowing: the objective source by which theology is communicated to us.

- In Reformed theology this is Holy Scripture, as the inscripturated Word of God.
- More broadly, some authors will include revelation in creation and providence as an external principium in a subordinate, non-saving sense, but in strict dogmatics “external principium” denotes Scripture as the norming revelation.
- Scripture, as God’s speech in creaturely form, is the ectypal revelation that mediates archetypal truth to viators; it is the cognitive “rule” (regula) of theology.

The external principium is therefore the concrete, historical, linguistic medium by which ectypal theology is delivered to the church.

### Principium cognoscendi internum

The **principium cognoscendi internum** is the internal principle of knowing: the subjective ground by which we actually come to know God through the external principium.

- It is the Holy Spirit’s work in the human subject, illumining the mind, renewing the heart, and producing faith.
- The Spirit grants a *habitus* of faith, removes the noetic effects of sin in a measure, and gives the internal testimony that Scripture is God’s Word.
- Without this internal principium, Scripture remains objectively true but is not savingly known or rightly interpreted by the sinner.

Thus, the internal principium concerns the epistemic renovation and disposition of the knower, not the content or external form of revelation.

## How These Principia Ground Analogical Knowledge

### Maintaining the Creator–creature distinction

The archetypal/ectypal distinction, anchored in the principium essendi, secures the qualitative difference between God’s knowledge and ours.

- Because God alone is the principium essendi and possesses archetypal theology, his knowledge is archetypally original, simple, and infinite.
- Our ectypal knowledge, even at its eschatological perfection, remains finite and receptive; it is never identical with God’s internal self-knowledge.

This asymmetry is what makes our knowledge analogical rather than univocal. The same predicates (wise, good, just) apply truly to God and to creatures, but they signify perfections that exist in God in an uncreated, infinite mode and in us in a created, finite mode.

### Ensuring genuine correspondence (avoiding equivocity)

At the same time, the principia prevent our knowledge from collapsing into sheer equivocity or skepticism.

- The external principium (Scripture) is not a human construct reaching up toward God; it is God’s own ectypal self-presentation, freely conformed to our capacities.
- Because Scripture is grounded in the archetypal knowledge of God (through the principium essendi) and produced by the Spirit, it reliably reproduces, in creaturely form, what God is and wills.

Therefore, while our concepts are not univocally identical with God’s own self-conception, they are not disconnected from it: they are designed by God to be apt signs of his being and works. Analogy here is a divinely instituted correspondence, not a projection.

### The role of the Spirit in analogical apprehension

The internal principium ensures that analogical revelation is actually recognized and appropriated as such.

- Sin would otherwise distort even a perfectly given ectypal revelation; the Spirit rectifies the cognitive and moral posture of the subject.
- The Spirit’s illumination does not grant archetypal knowledge; it grants a right, saving, and progressively clearer grasp of ectypal revelation.
- Thus, analogicality is preserved: we do not ascend into God’s self-knowledge; instead, God, by his Spirit, brings us into a faithful, creaturely participation in ectypal theology.

### Integration

- **Ontological ground (principium essendi / archetypal theology):** guarantees that theology has a real object and that God’s own knowledge is the pattern for all truth about him, while preserving his incomprehensibility.
- **Objective cognitive ground (principium cognoscendi externum / Scripture):** provides a determinate, God-given ectypal revelation that truly corresponds to God, enabling non-arbitrary predication about him.
- **Subjective cognitive ground (principium cognoscendi internum / Spirit’s work):** actualizes this revelation in the human subject, so that our analogical concepts are not merely available but rightly embraced and used.

Together, these principia entail that our knowledge of God is neither univocal with God’s self-knowledge nor equivocally disconnected from it, but is a Spirit-wrought, Scripturally grounded, ectypal participation in the archetypal truth of God according to a genuinely analogical mode.

Historical and Conceptual Background

The archetypal/ectypal distinction and the principia language arise in post-Reformation scholasticism as a way to safeguard both divine incomprehensibility and the truth of theological knowledge. Reformed authors adapt earlier medieval themes but sharpen them under the pressure of the Creator–creature distinction and sola Scriptura.

These distinctions function together to answer two questions:

  • What kind of knowledge does God have of himself, and what kind of knowledge can creatures have of God?
  • What are the basic grounds and sources by which theology exists and is possible?

Archetypal and Ectypal Knowledge

Archetypal theology

“Archetypal” theology (theologia archetypa) is God’s own knowledge of himself.

  • It is identical with God’s simple, infinite essence; it is not a habit or acquired science but God himself knowing himself.
  • It is necessary, underived, comprehensive, and immediate; there is no gap between object, act, and content of knowing.
  • It is incommunicable as such to creatures; a creature cannot be made omniscient or simple, and so cannot participate in archetypal theology.

Archetypal theology is therefore the self-knowledge of the triune God as he is in se, and it is the ultimate pattern and ground of all true theology, but never an object of direct creaturely possession.

Ectypal theology

“Ectypal” theology (theologia ectypa) is theology “copied from” or “impressed by” the archetype into a creaturely mode.

  • It is finite, discursive, habitus-like knowledge that God freely wills into existence.
  • It is analogical: truly corresponding to God as he is, because patterned on the archetypal knowledge, yet proportioned to creaturely capacities.
  • It appears in distinct modes:
    • In the theologia unionis (the knowledge of the incarnate Son according to his human mind).
    • In the theologia visionis (the immediate knowledge of the blessed in glory).
    • In the theologia viatorum (the pilgrim theology of believers on earth, mediated through revelation in word and sacrament).

The crucial point is that all creaturely theology, whether of Christ’s human mind, the saints in glory, or believers now, is ectypal: finite, receptive, and derivative, yet ordered to and conformed to the archetypal knowledge of God.

The Principia of Theology

Reformed scholastics analyze theology in terms of its “principles” or foundations.

Principium essendi

The principium essendi is the principle of being of theology: that which makes theology possible in reality.

  • It is God himself, the triune Lord, as he exists and knows himself.
  • Because God alone is self-existent and self-knowing, he is the ontological ground of all theology; apart from his being and his archetypal knowledge, neither revelation nor theology could exist.
  • All ectypal knowledge presupposes that God is and that God knows; theology is possible only because God is the principium essendi of it.

Thus, the principium essendi is not a source that we consult but the metaphysical reality in virtue of which there can even be something called “knowledge of God.”

Principium cognoscendi externum

The principium cognoscendi externum is the external principle of knowing: the objective source by which theology is communicated to us.

  • In Reformed theology this is Holy Scripture, as the inscripturated Word of God.
  • More broadly, some authors will include revelation in creation and providence as an external principium in a subordinate, non-saving sense, but in strict dogmatics “external principium” denotes Scripture as the norming revelation.
  • Scripture, as God’s speech in creaturely form, is the ectypal revelation that mediates archetypal truth to viators; it is the cognitive “rule” (regula) of theology.

The external principium is therefore the concrete, historical, linguistic medium by which ectypal theology is delivered to the church.

Principium cognoscendi internum

The principium cognoscendi internum is the internal principle of knowing: the subjective ground by which we actually come to know God through the external principium.

  • It is the Holy Spirit’s work in the human subject, illumining the mind, renewing the heart, and producing faith.
  • The Spirit grants a habitus of faith, removes the noetic effects of sin in a measure, and gives the internal testimony that Scripture is God’s Word.
  • Without this internal principium, Scripture remains objectively true but is not savingly known or rightly interpreted by the sinner.

Thus, the internal principium concerns the epistemic renovation and disposition of the knower, not the content or external form of revelation.

How These Principia Ground Analogical Knowledge

Maintaining the Creator–creature distinction

The archetypal/ectypal distinction, anchored in the principium essendi, secures the qualitative difference between God’s knowledge and ours.

  • Because God alone is the principium essendi and possesses archetypal theology, his knowledge is archetypally original, simple, and infinite.
  • Our ectypal knowledge, even at its eschatological perfection, remains finite and receptive; it is never identical with God’s internal self-knowledge.

This asymmetry is what makes our knowledge analogical rather than univocal. The same predicates (wise, good, just) apply truly to God and to creatures, but they signify perfections that exist in God in an uncreated, infinite mode and in us in a created, finite mode.

Ensuring genuine correspondence (avoiding equivocity)

At the same time, the principia prevent our knowledge from collapsing into sheer equivocity or skepticism.

  • The external principium (Scripture) is not a human construct reaching up toward God; it is God’s own ectypal self-presentation, freely conformed to our capacities.
  • Because Scripture is grounded in the archetypal knowledge of God (through the principium essendi) and produced by the Spirit, it reliably reproduces, in creaturely form, what God is and wills.

Therefore, while our concepts are not univocally identical with God’s own self-conception, they are not disconnected from it: they are designed by God to be apt signs of his being and works. Analogy here is a divinely instituted correspondence, not a projection.

The role of the Spirit in analogical apprehension

The internal principium ensures that analogical revelation is actually recognized and appropriated as such.

  • Sin would otherwise distort even a perfectly given ectypal revelation; the Spirit rectifies the cognitive and moral posture of the subject.
  • The Spirit’s illumination does not grant archetypal knowledge; it grants a right, saving, and progressively clearer grasp of ectypal revelation.
  • Thus, analogicality is preserved: we do not ascend into God’s self-knowledge; instead, God, by his Spirit, brings us into a faithful, creaturely participation in ectypal theology.

Integration

  • Ontological ground (principium essendi / archetypal theology): guarantees that theology has a real object and that God’s own knowledge is the pattern for all truth about him, while preserving his incomprehensibility.
  • Objective cognitive ground (principium cognoscendi externum / Scripture): provides a determinate, God-given ectypal revelation that truly corresponds to God, enabling non-arbitrary predication about him.
  • Subjective cognitive ground (principium cognoscendi internum / Spirit’s work): actualizes this revelation in the human subject, so that our analogical concepts are not merely available but rightly embraced and used.

Together, these principia entail that our knowledge of God is neither univocal with God’s self-knowledge nor equivocally disconnected from it, but is a Spirit-wrought, Scripturally grounded, ectypal participation in the archetypal truth of God according to a genuinely analogical mode.

top_exam_questions.question: You describe Aquinas’s analogia entis as a ‘continuum between our creational being and divine being.’ How would you correct and nuance that description in light of Aquinas’s own insistence on an infinite Creator–creature distinction?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Historical and Metaphysical Setting

Aquinas’s doctrine of **analogia entis** operates within a strongly affirmed Creator–creature distinction. He is not a pantheist, nor does he posit a graded chain of being collapsing God and creatures into a single ontological spectrum.

Key metaphysical commitments:

- **God as ipsum esse subsistens.** God is not one “instance” of being among others but subsistent being itself. Every creature has being; only God is his being.
- **Real distinction in creatures, identity in God.** In creatures, essence and existence are really distinct; in God they are identical. This marks an absolute asymmetry between divine and created being.
- **Participation.** Created being is a participated likeness of the uncreated act of being. Creatures are not “parts” of God nor graduations of the same being, but finite participations in a perfection that is fully and identically realized only in God.

Thus there is a genuine **infinite ontological interval** between God and creatures; analogy is Aquinas’s way of safeguarding this, not eroding it.

## Aquinas’s Doctrine of Analogy

When Aquinas speaks of analogia entis at the linguistic and conceptual level, he has especially in view **predication** about God and creatures: how we can truly say “God is good” and “this man is good” without either univocity or sheer equivocity.

Aquinas rejects:

- **Pure univocity**: that “good” means exactly the same in God and creatures. This would compromise divine simplicity and aseity by subordinating God and creatures under a common genus of “goodness.”
- **Pure equivocity**: that “good” has wholly different meanings when applied to God and creatures. This would render theology and revelation unintelligible.

He insists instead on **analogical predication**:

- Terms are **partly the same and partly different in ratio** when applied to God and creatures.
- The likeness is always founded on a **causal relation**: the creature’s perfection is an effect and participated likeness of the uncreated perfection in God.
- The **mode** of the perfection differs radically: in God, perfections are identical with the divine essence and with one another; in creatures they are finite, received, and really distinct from essence.

So, “analogy of being” refers above all to this **ordered relation of likeness and dependence** in predication grounded in participation, not to a metaphysical blending of Creator and creature.

## Correcting the “Continuum” Language

Describing Aquinas’s view as a “continuum between our creational being and divine being” is potentially misleading in several ways.

First, it suggests a **single ontological scale** on which God and creatures appear as differing only by degree. Aquinas explicitly denies that:

- God is outside every genus.
- No univocal “being” applies to both God and creatures as a genus.
- The difference is not quantitative (more/less being) but qualitative (uncreated/created, necessary/contingent, pure act/composites of act and potency).

Second, it can obscure the **asymmetry of causality and participation**:

- Creatures possess perfections *derivatively* and *dependently* as effects.
- God possesses them *primitively* and *eminently* as cause, in a mode utterly incommensurable with creatures.

Analogy, therefore, is not a halfway house between univocity and equivocity along a shared continuum; it is a different kind of relation: **ordered similarity within radical ontological dissimilarity**.

A better formulation would be:

- There is a **real analogy of being** between God and creatures, insofar as creatures participate in and reflect the perfections that are in God in an eminent and identical way.
- This analogy presupposes and protects an **infinite Creator–creature distinction** grounded in God’s simplicity and his identity with his own act of being, over against all finite, composed, participated beings.

## Evaluation from a Reformed Perspective

From a classic Reformed standpoint, two points are crucial in nuancing Aquinas fairly:

- Reformed theology likewise insists on an **absolute Creator–creature distinction**, though it often frames analogy more explicitly in terms of **covenant and revelation** rather than a metaphysics of participation.
- Critiques of the analogia entis as a “continuum” should acknowledge that Aquinas himself is at pains to deny any **common genus of being** shared univocally by God and creatures.

Where a Reformed critique rightly presses Aquinas is not that he erases the Creator–creature gulf, but that his account of natural knowledge of God and of analogy can be seen as granting too much to autonomous reason and to speculative metaphysics apart from special revelation and its noetic implications. That, however, is a distinct issue from accusing him of a simple ontological continuum.

In light of Aquinas’s emphatic teaching on God as ipsum esse subsistens and on creaturely participation, his analogia entis is best understood not as a continuum of being but as an ordered likeness of participated perfections that presupposes an infinite Creator–creature distinction.

top_exam_questions.question: How do you reconcile a strong doctrine of divine incomprehensibility and categorical difference with the claim that statements like ‘God is good’ or ‘God is just’ are true and not merely equivocal? In what sense are these predicates the same and in what sense different when applied to God and creatures?
top_exam_questions.answer_markdown:
## Doctrinal framing: incomprehensibility and analogical predication

A strong Reformed doctrine of divine incomprehensibility begins with the Creator–creature distinction. God is simple, infinite, self-sufficient, and knows himself and all things in one eternal, archetypal act. Creatures are composite, finite, dependent, and know discursively and ectypally. There is therefore no common genus of “being” or “knowledge” under which God and creatures fall as two instances.

Yet Scripture predicates creaturely terms of God: “God is good,” “God is just,” “God is wise.” If these predicates were univocal, God and creatures would be instances of a shared property under a higher concept, collapsing the Creator–creature distinction. If they were purely equivocal, no genuine knowledge or worship would be possible, since the same words would designate wholly unrelated realities. The Reformed answer is that such predicates are **analogical**: genuinely same in one respect, really different in another.

Divine incomprehensibility, then, is not ignorance of God, but the impossibility that God be contained within a created concept or exhausted by finite cognition. We know God truly, yet never as he knows himself.

## In what sense “the same”?

When we say “God is good” and “this man is good,” there is a real, God-ordained continuity in the predicate.

- **Same reference to a real perfection.** Both predications concern what is, in some sense, one perfection: goodness, justice, wisdom. There is not one goodness in God and an unrelated goodness in creatures; there is one order of created participation in perfections that exist archetypally in God himself.

- **Same rule by divine naming.** God himself has taught us these terms in revelation. He names himself “good,” “just,” “righteous,” and then names his acts and people with related terms. The semantic continuity is not constructed from below but instituted from above by a divine pedagogy.

- **Same moral and cognitive orientation.** The terms direct us in the same moral direction:
    - “God is good” and “this is a good act” are both commendatory claims, not contradictory moral valuations.
    - “God is just” and “this judge is just” both affirm rectitude in judgment according to right.

- **Same capacity to ground inference.** Because the predicates are not merely equivocal, they sustain valid reasoning:
    - From “God is just” we can infer that he will not pervert justice.
    - From “God is good” we can infer that he does no moral evil.
  Such inferences are not possible if the terms are totally unrelated in sense.

Thus there is a genuine sameness: our predicates correspond to realities in God and in creatures according to a divinely established pattern of likeness, sufficient for true, doctrinally significant knowledge.

## In what sense “different”?

The sameness is qualified by deeper and more decisive differences.

### Difference in mode of possession

- **In God:** Goodness and justice are identical with God’s simple essence. God does not “have” goodness as one quality among others. God is his goodness, his justice, his wisdom.

- **In creatures:** Goodness and justice are accidents or qualities distinct from the essence, received and limited, capable of increase or loss. A just human can become unjust; God cannot.

Consequently, “good” and “just” as predicated of God signify an infinite, underived perfection that is identical with God’s being, whereas in creatures they signify finite, derived habits or properties.

### Difference in ontological status

- **In God:** Perfections are underived, necessary, and absolute; God is the measure of goodness and justice.

- **In creatures:** Perfections are participated, contingent, and relative; creatures are measured by God’s goodness and justice and can approximate or deviate.

Thus “good” in God is the archetype; “good” in creatures is an ectypal participation. The perfection is numerically distinct in creatures, though really patterned on God.

### Difference in epistemic mode

- **Divine knowledge:** Intuitive, comprehensive, non-discursive. God knows goodness simply by knowing himself.

- **Creaturely knowledge:** Discursive, analogical, partial. We abstract the notion of goodness from created instances and then, by revelation, learn that all genuine goodness reflects and derives from God.

So even when we ascribe the same predicate, we do so under a creaturely, conceptual mode that never captures the infinite fulness of what “good” is in God.

### Difference in semantic depth

The analogical structure means that while there is a core of shared meaning, the “depth” of the predicate in God exceeds what the same word expresses in creatures.

- When we say “this man is just,” we speak of conformity to a standard beyond him.
- When we say “God is just,” we speak of the very standard itself, which also entails:
    - infallible judgment,
    - pure self-consistency,
    - eschatological rectification of all wrong.

The word “just” can be applied to both, but in God it penetrates to a qualitatively higher order of reality that cannot be fully unfolded in creaturely terms.

## Avoiding univocity and equivocity

### Against univocity

Reformed theology rejects univocity at the level of the ultimate metaphysical account of the predicate.

- Predicates cannot be univocal between God and creatures because:
    - God is not one item within a genus; he is the source of every genus.
    - Simplicity and aseity mean that no predicate applies to God as one instance among others.
- Univocity would either:
    - reduce God to a being alongside others; or
    - absolutize created concepts as if they were adequate measures of the divine.

Thus even when the same term is employed, the way it is grounded in reality is incommensurably different.

### Against mere equivocity

At the same time, Reformed theology rejects the idea that religious language is merely equivocal.

- Equivocity would destroy revelation and covenant:
    - If “good” in “God is good” had no ordered relation to “good” as we know it, we would lack any criterion for understanding or trusting God’s self-revelation.
- Instead, God himself establishes analogical correspondence by:
    - creating humans in his image with a capacity for moral and intellectual likeness;
    - revealing himself through acts and words that exhibit perfections in creaturely forms;
    - interpreting those acts in Scripture, thereby fixing the analogical usage.

The predicates are therefore anchored in God’s sovereign self-communication, not in a neutral metaphysical continuum.

## Positive formulation: analogical truth of “God is good” and “God is just”

Putting this together, the truth of statements like “God is good” or “God is just” can be expressed along three axes.

- **Ontological axis:** God is the living fullness and source of the perfections signified. Creatures are derivative copies or participations. Predication reflects an ordered relation of archetype to ectype.

- **Epistemic axis:** Our concepts are true as far as they go, because they are formed under God’s revelatory instruction, but they are not exhaustive. Every true predicate of God signals more than it explicitly conveys.

- **Semantic axis:** There is a controlled stretch in meaning:
    - enough continuity that the term can function in assertion, promise, and worship;
    - enough qualified difference that the Creator–creature distinction, simplicity, and incomprehensibility are preserved.

Thus “God is good” and “God is just” are true because they analogically express that the perfections faintly reflected in creatures subsist infinitely, simply, and archetypally in God himself.

## Restatement of the issue

The criticism is that the essay treated “knowledge by analogy” largely by contrast—against univocal and equivocal conceptions, against the analogia entis, etc.—without giving a crisp, positive definition of what analogical knowledge is in Reformed theology: what sort of relation it is between God’s knowledge and ours, how it arises, and what it positively implies about the content and mode of our cognition of God.

## Doctrinal analysis: defining analogical knowledge

From a classic Reformed standpoint, “knowledge by analogy” is best defined in relation to two fundamental principles:

- The **Creator–creature distinction**: God and the creature do not share a common genus of being or knowing.
- The **reality and adequacy of revelation**: God truly makes himself known in his works and Word.

Against that background, a positive, analytic definition can be stated as follows:

**Knowledge by analogy is the finite, ectypal apprehension of God and his works, in which our judgments correspond to how God knows himself and his works, not by sharing the same mode or depth of cognition, but by being a creaturely replica, instituted and measured by God’s own archetypal knowledge.**

Several elements are essential.

### Archetypal and ectypal knowledge

Reformed scholasticism formulates the relation in terms of **archetypal** and **ectypal** theology.

- **Archetypal knowledge** is God’s own self-knowledge: simple, necessary, identical with his being, comprehensive, and creative.
- **Ectypal knowledge** is the finite “copy” of that knowledge as it exists in creatures, produced by revelation and accommodated to the creature’s capacity.

Analogical knowledge, then, is not a middle term between ignorance and truth, but the **proper mode of true knowledge for a creature**: the way in which a dependent mind can genuinely grasp what is first and fully known in the independent mind of God.

### Similarity and dissimilarity

Analogy introduces a **structured relation of similarity-in-dissimilarity**:

- There is a **similarity of reference and truth**: when we predicate “God is wise,” the subject really is God, and the predicate truly signifies a perfection that belongs to him.
- There is a **dissimilarity of mode and proportion**: God’s wisdom is identical with his essence, infinite and underived; our wisdom is finite, habitual, received. The concept “wisdom” functions differently in God and in us.

Analogical predication holds that:

- The **same term** (e.g., “good,” “wise,” “just”) is used of God and creatures without pure equivocation; there is a real connection in meaning grounded in divine authorship.
- Yet the term is not univocal, because the most fundamental determination of its content (infinite, simple, underived in God; finite, composite, derived in creatures) differs.

Thus, analogical knowledge is **modally and proportionally distinct** from God’s own knowledge, while being **materially and referentially corresponding** to it by divine appointment.

### Revelation and covenantal accommodation

Within Reformed theology this analogical relation is not grounded in a metaphysical continuum of “being” (as in the classic analogia entis), but in **covenantal revelation**:

- God freely **accommodates** his self-disclosure to creaturely capacities in creation, providence, and especially Scripture.
- The forms of our knowledge—concepts, judgments, inferences—are **ordered to reality** by God’s creative and revelatory act, such that:

    - They genuinely track what God has willed and done.
    - They never escape the limits of creaturely finitude and dependence.

On this view, analogical knowledge is simply **“thinking God’s thoughts after him”**: our cognitive acts are derivative, receptive, and interpretive replicas of the divine archetype, enabled and normed by revelation and the Spirit.

### Contrast with univocalism and equivocalism

Given this positive account, the differences can be stated precisely:

- Against **univocalism**, Reformed analogical knowledge denies a shared genus of “being” or “knowing” between Creator and creature; predications about God and creatures cannot be grounded in a common ontological platform.
- Against **equivocalism**, it affirms that God is the author of both reality and revelation, so the concepts he gives us are intentionally fitted to the realities they signify; analogical distance does not entail semantic disconnection.

Hence, analogical knowledge is **true, dependable, and revelationally grounded**, but always finite, receptive, and asymptotically short of God’s own comprehensive self-knowledge.

## Concise resolution

Knowledge by analogy, in the Reformed confessional sense, is our finite, revelationally grounded grasp of God and his works as an ectypal replica of God’s archetypal self-knowledge—truly corresponding to what God knows, yet irreducibly distinct in mode, proportion, and depth because of the Creator–creature distinction.

## Restatement of the issue

The weakness is that the essay simply asserted: because God is categorically and absolutely different from man (Creator–creature distinction), therefore all our knowledge of God is analogical. What was missing were the intermediate steps explaining why that ontological distinction entails an analogical, rather than univocal or equivocal, relation between divine and human knowledge.

## Doctrinal analysis: from Creator–creature distinction to analogy

The Reformed tradition begins with two coordinated affirmations:

- **Creator–creature distinction:** God is self-existent, simple, infinite, and independent; creatures are dependent, composite, finite.
- **Covenantal revelation:** This God truly makes himself known to creatures in creation and especially in Scripture.

From these premises, several steps follow.

**First**, God’s knowledge and our knowledge differ in mode and ground.

- God’s knowledge is **archetypal**: he knows all things in knowing himself, by a single, eternal act, grounded in his own simple being and decree.
- Human knowledge is **ectypal**: it is derivative, temporal, discursive, acquired by reception and inference, grounded in God’s revelation and providential order.

Because of divine simplicity and aseity, nothing outside God can constitute or determine his knowledge; because of creaturely dependence, everything about our knowledge is constituted and determined by God’s creative and revelatory act. This already rules out strict univocity of knowledge-content considered as existing in the same mode.

**Second**, the Creator–creature distinction excludes both univocity and pure equivocity, leaving analogy as the only coherent option.

- **Univocal predication** would require that the same concept exist in God and in us under the same formal ratio. But:
  
    - In God, “wisdom,” for example, is identical with his essence and with all his other “attributes.”
    - In us, “wisdom” is a finite quality, acquired, mutable, distinct from our essence and from our other properties.

  The formal structure of the concept “wise” cannot be literally identical in God and in us without denying either divine simplicity or creaturely finitude. Hence, no strict univocity is possible without collapsing Creator and creature.

- **Equivocal predication** would mean that the same word used of God and of creatures has no shared intelligible content. But:
  
    - Scripture predicates creaturely terms of God with the evident intent to communicate real truth (good, just, merciful, knowing, personal).
    - The Reformed confessions insist that theology is a true science, that the church truly knows God in Jesus Christ by the Spirit.

  Pure equivocity would render revelation unintelligible and destroy the possibility of doctrinal formulation and worship “in spirit and truth.” Hence, equivocity is impossible without collapsing revelation into skepticism.

**Third**, analogy follows from God’s self-determining accommodation.

The key Reformed move is to treat analogy not as a metaphysical continuum of being (analogia entis), but as a **covenantal, revelational relation**:

- God, who is categorically other, **freely condescends** to speak in creaturely forms (language, concepts, images) in such a way that:
  
    - The content expressed corresponds truly to what he is,
    - Yet is proportioned to, and limited by, the creaturely mode of reception.

- Thus, our concepts are:
  
    - **Positively related** to God’s own truth (since he determines them in revelation);  
    - **Negatively qualified** by creatureliness and finitude (since they never comprehend God as he knows himself).

This is what classic Reformed scholastics mean by:

- Archetypal versus ectypal theology.
- The doctrine that all true knowledge of God is **“from him, through him, and to him”**, yet always “in part.”

The Creator–creature distinction is therefore not a bare separation; it is the ground for understanding why the only way finite minds can know the infinite God is via concepts that are:

- Truly about God (against equivocity),
- Not identical in mode or content with God’s self-knowledge (against univocity),
- Proportionate and derivative, determined by God’s revelatory self-accommodation (analogy).

**Fourth**, analogical knowledge is ordered by the asymmetry of Lordship.

The dependence relation is one-way:

- God’s knowledge is the **archetype**; ours is the **reproduced copy** at a creaturely level.
- When we predicate “God is good,” the truth of the statement is measured not by some shared neutral standard, but by God’s own self-interpretation in revelation.

Analogy, in this sense, is not a middle compromise between univocity and equivocity, but the epistemic correlate of:

- Divine aseity and simplicity,
- Creaturely dependence,
- God’s sovereign act of making himself known.

Given these, **all** our knowledge of God must be analogical, because there is no case in which our concepts escape creaturely limitation, nor any case in which God’s own self-knowledge ceases to be archetypal and simple.

## Conclusion

From a Reformed standpoint, the categorical Creator–creature distinction, together with God’s real yet accommodated self-revelation, entails that our knowledge of God cannot be univocal or equivocal but must be analogical: truly about God, grounded in his own self-knowledge, yet always in a finite, derivative, and non-comprehensive mode.

logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The problematic claim is that Reformed theology “appreciates equivocalism” because it upholds divine incomprehensibility. Left as stated, this suggests that there is some genuinely equivocal element in our God-talk, alongside the Reformed insistence that we possess true knowledge of God. The tension is: if our predicates are equivocal, they do not touch God at all; if they are not equivocal, in what sense can we speak of incomprehensibility without sliding into univocity? The missing piece is a precise account of how Reformed theology rejects strict equivocity while still affirming both incomprehensibility and truth.

## Doctrinal analysis

Classic Reformed theology works with three basic categories for predication about God:

- **Univocal predication**: the same term has exactly the same meaning when applied to God and creatures (e.g., “wise” means identically the same thing in both cases).
- **Equivocal predication**: the same term has completely different meanings, so that there is no conceptual overlap (e.g., “wise” of God and “wise” of humans would be sheer homonymy).
- **Analogical predication**: the same term has a related, proportionally ordered meaning, grounded in a real but asymmetrical relation between God and creatures.

Reformed theology identifies the first two as errors when applied to the Creator–creature relation:

- Univocity compromises the absolute dependence of creaturely being and knowledge on God and tends toward putting God and creatures on a common scale.
- Equivocity destroys the very possibility of revelation and theology; if “wise,” “good,” or “just” are equivocal, then revelation cannot inform us who God is.

The confessional tradition therefore insists that all predication about God is **analogical**, not partly univocal and partly equivocal, and certainly not a patchwork of three types. The key distinction is between:

- **Incomprehensibility**: we never grasp God’s essence exhaustively or proportionately to his own knowledge.
- **Ineffability/equivocity**: we cannot say anything about God that truly corresponds to who he is.

Reformed theology affirms incomprehensibility but denies ineffability and equivocity.

## How incomprehensibility and truth cohere

The coherence rests on the principial Creator–creature distinction and on archetypal/ectypal knowledge.

### Archetypal and ectypal knowledge

- **Archetypal knowledge** is God’s own self-knowledge: simple, infinite, immediate, and comprehensive. God knows himself and all things in knowing himself.
- **Ectypal knowledge** is the finite replica of that knowledge as communicated to creatures. It is always dependent, partial, and accommodated.

When we say “God is good,” our predicate:

- does not name a quality in God as if goodness were one item among others in him;
- does truly correspond to God as he reveals himself, because the content is a finite ectype of his archetypal knowledge;
- is analogical, because what “goodness” is in God (identical with his essence, infinite, simple) differs in mode and proportion from what goodness is in us (finite habitus, participated quality).

Thus, the same word “good” is neither strictly univocal (since the mode and ontological status of goodness differ radically) nor strictly equivocal (since the creaturely participation is a divinely ordered likeness of the divine perfection), but truly analogical.

### Incomprehensibility as qualitative excess, not equivocality

Divine incomprehensibility is then construed as the **qualitative excess** of the archetypal over the ectypal:

- Our concepts are always **proportionate to our created mode of being**, not to God’s infinite fullness.
- Yet God himself determines a real correspondence by **freely accommodating** his self-knowledge to us in revelation.

So, what appears “like equivocalism” from a purely philosophical standpoint is actually:

- not an admission that our terms fail to reach God,
- but the denial that our finite concepts can ever capture God as he is in himself in an exhaustive or coextensive way.

The distance is ontological and noetic, not semantic in the sense of sheer homonymy.

## Clarification of the earlier claim

Instead of saying that Reformed theology “appreciates equivocalism,” it is more precise to say:

- Reformed theology **shares with the equivocalist** the insistence that God’s being and knowledge are not on a continuum with ours and are never comprehended by us.
- But it **rejects equivocalism** itself, because it affirms that God’s self-revelation yields true, though analogical, knowledge of the living God.

Thus the apparent “equivocal” element is only this: any similarity between God and creatures is always accompanied by a greater dissimilarity, and our knowledge never encloses God. Yet that dissimilarity does not destroy likeness, because the likeness is created and interpreted by God himself.

In classic Reformed terms, therefore, there is no genuinely equivocal predication about God; there is incomprehensible but nevertheless true, analogical knowledge grounded in God’s archetypal self-knowledge and freely given ectypal revelation.

## Restatement of the issue

The weakness lies in treating Duns Scotus’s univocity as if he claimed that the content and mode of our knowing are simply identical to God’s, as though univocity collapsed the Creator–creature distinction into a flat sameness of cognition. That misrepresents Scotus’s actual position, which concerns univocity of concepts or predicates, not an identity of the way God and creatures know. A Reformed account must distinguish these carefully and then evaluate univocity on the right terms.

## Doctrinal and philosophical clarification

### Scotus: univocity of concept, not mode

Scotus’s doctrine of univocity is directed to the problem of meaningful predication about God. His concern is largely semantic and logical: how can “God is good” and “Socrates is good” be more than a mere pun?

- Scotus affirms a **univocity of concept or formal notion**: the concept signified by “being” or “good” is not merely equivocally different when applied to God and creatures. There is at least one concept (ens, for example) under which God and creatures can be conceived and of which we can predicated truly.
- At the same time, Scotus does not say that God and creatures share a **univocal mode of being** or a **univocal mode of knowing**. God’s intellect is infinite, simple, wholly actual; ours is finite, composite, discursive.
- Thus the univocity is **at the level of the ratio conceptus** (the formal content of the concept), not at the level of metaphysical status or cognitive act.

So a fair summary is: Scotus holds that there is at least one concept that applies in the same formal sense to both God and creatures, without thereby making God and creatures the same kind of being or knower.

### Univocity and the Reformed Creator–creature distinction

From a classic Reformed standpoint, the central concern is not to caricature Scotus but to show why univocity at the level of core concepts is problematic in light of the absolute Creator–creature distinction.

- Reformed theology affirms an **essential qualitative difference** between God’s being and knowledge and ours. God is independent, simple, self-interpreting; creatures are dependent, composite, receptive.
- This difference grounds a corresponding distinction in **archetypal vs. ectypal knowledge**:
    - God’s knowledge of himself and all things is archetypal, founding and measure of all truth.
    - Creaturely knowledge is ectypal: a finite, derived, accommodated replication, structured by revelation.
- Because of this, the Reformed tradition speaks of **analogy**, not univocity, in our predication about God. The same word (“wise,” “good,” “being”) signifies truly, but the way in which the attribute exists in God and in us is not captured by a single, genus-like concept.

Properly stated, then, the Reformed objection is not that Scotus crassly identified God’s and man’s knowing, but that granting a univocal concept common to God and creatures **tends** to treat God and creatures as falling under a higher logical commonality (“being”) that is conceptually prior to the Creator–creature distinction. That is incompatible with the Reformed insistence that God is not one instance within a broader category but the absolute ontological source of all categories.

### Reformed analogical knowledge and predication

Clarifying the Reformed alternative requires care not to drift into equivocity.

- **Against equivocity**, Reformed theology insists that our concepts of God, given by his self-revelation, are genuinely cognitive: God is really wise, really good, really just, and we truly know something of what these mean.
- **Against univocity**, it insists that these predicates apply to God and creatures in ways irreducibly conditioned by God’s aseity and simplicity on the one side, and our dependence and finitude on the other. There is no neutral core concept of “being” or “goodness” that is first defined apart from God and then applied to him.
- Thus:
    - Predicates are **analogical**: the same term, grounded in God’s own self-description, applies to God as the original, and to creatures as derivative.
    - God’s knowledge is **archetypal**; ours is ectypal and covenantal, “thinking God’s thoughts after him,” not sharing a common genus of cognition with God.

From this standpoint, univocity of concept, even without claiming identity of mode of knowing, is judged defective because it introduces an abstract conceptual unity (“being,” “goodness” in general) as if it were epistemically more fundamental than God’s concrete, triune self-revelation as the living Lord.

### Corrected formulation of the objection

The Reformed critique should therefore be framed as follows:

- Scotus does not make God’s and man’s knowledge simply “the same”; he distinguishes mode and degree.
- However, by positing a formally univocal concept common to God and creatures, Scotus places God and creatures under a higher, conceptually prior unity.
- The Reformed confession of the Creator–creature distinction, together with archetypal/ectypal epistemology, refuses such a higher unity and insists that the very intelligibility of “being” and “goodness” is from and in God’s self-revelation, so that our predication is necessarily analogical, not univocal.

Properly stated, then, the Reformed position holds that Scotus’s univocity concerns shared conceptual content rather than identical cognitive mode, but is still rejected because any such shared concept compromises the principial primacy of God’s own being and knowledge as the source and measure of all creaturely predication.

logic_weaknesses.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under weak_spots/logic_weaknesses:

The essay conflates several distinct questions—universals, causality, divine simplicity, and noetic effects—without showing how each is logically necessary for the Reformed analogical position, producing a loose, associative rather than tightly argued structure.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The criticism is that the essay mentioned many topics—universals and particulars, causality, divine simplicity, and the noetic effects of sin—but treated them as if their relevance to analogical knowledge were obvious, instead of showing in a principled way how each bears, in a logically necessary way, on the Reformed doctrine that our knowledge of God is analogical, not univocal or equivocal. The result was suggestive rather than argumentative.

## Doctrinal analysis: what “analogy” actually needs

The Reformed doctrine of analogical knowledge rests formally on two coordinated claims:

- **Creator–creature distinction:** God is ontologically distinct, self-existent, and independent; creation is contingent, dependent, and ectypal.
- **Revelatory condescension:** This God freely accommodates himself to creatures in covenant and revelation so that they truly know him, yet never as he knows himself.

From that standpoint, the auxiliary topics you raised function as *conditions of intelligibility* for those two core claims. Properly ordered, they play distinct roles.

### Universals and analogy

The universals/particulars issue matters for analogy only at one precise point: whether there can be a real likeness between God and creatures without collapsing them into a shared genus.

- If universals are taken in a way that posits a **common ontological genus of “being”** in which God and creatures both participate, then the analogy of being (analogia entis) tends toward a graded univocity: “being,” “goodness,” etc. are the same in kind, differing only in mode or degree.
- Reformed theology, grounded in the Creator–creature distinction, rejects any such overarching genus. God is not the highest instance of a class called “being”; he is the one who *gives* being.
- Thus, universals must be located **primarily in God’s archetypal knowledge**, with creaturely instantiations as ectypal reflections. The “commonality” is not an abstract genus above God and creatures, but the creative, revelatory wisdom of God himself.

So the universals discussion is needed to underwrite this: analogy does not rest on a shared metaphysical middle term, but on God’s free decision to create finite reflections of his perfections.

### Causality and analogy

Causality is relevant not because cosmological arguments are central, but because it clarifies the direction and dependence of our knowing.

- The order of being is **from God as first cause to creatures as effects**; the order of our knowing proceeds from effects to the knowledge of their cause.
- In classical theism, including Reformed orthodoxy, God’s causality is not one cause among others, but the transcendent, sustaining cause of all that exists.
- That asymmetry grounds analogy: what we know in creatures (goodness, power, wisdom) is **an effect of God’s causal action**, not a co-ordinate reality that we then simply project onto God.

Thus causality is needed to explain how our concepts, drawn from creatures, can truly refer to God: they refer to him as the transcendent source whose causal imprint they bear, not as an item within the same causal nexus.

### Divine simplicity and analogy

Divine simplicity is necessary to prevent univocity at the level of God’s own being and knowledge.

- If God’s attributes were really distinct parts, identifiable by concepts that carve up reality as ours do, then **our conceptual distinctions would map univocally onto distinct constituents in God**.
- Simplicity insists: God’s being and attributes are identical; his knowledge is identical with his essence; he knows all things in one simple act.
- Therefore, when we speak analogically of God as wise, just, or good, each predicate corresponds to **the same simple reality in God**, while signifying partially and discursively in us.

Simplicity is thus not a detachable metaphysical add-on; it is precisely what blocks a univocal transfer of our fragmented concepts into God, and so forces an analogical construal of all predication about him.

### Noetic effects of sin and analogy

The noetic effects of sin are not the reason for analogy as such; analogy is grounded in finitude and Creator–creature distinction. But sin introduces a further, ethical necessity.

- Even as creatures, we would always know God finitely and analogically; our concepts can never be comprehensive or archetypal.
- Sin adds **suppression and distortion** to finitude. General revelation remains clear objectively, but is misinterpreted subjectively.
- Hence, the principium cognoscendi in Reformed theology is **special revelation in Scripture, illuminated by the Spirit**, which provides the authoritative, God-given analogical content by which we may “think God’s thoughts after him.”

Sin therefore makes it impossible to rest our analogical knowledge on unaided reason’s ascent from effects to cause; it drives us to acknowledge that the *adequacy* of analogy depends on God’s inscripturated self-interpretation.

## Integrated, non-associative structure

Putting these elements together in a non-associative way:

- **Creator–creature distinction and simplicity** establish that God’s being and knowledge are archetypal, simple, and incommunicable as such; therefore univocal predication is impossible.
- **Universals and causality understood theistically** show that whatever “likeness” exists between God and creatures is not a shared genus but a created reflection of divine perfections in effects caused and ordered by God; therefore equivocalism is false, because there is a real, God-grounded likeness.
- **Noetic effects and the principium cognoscendi** locate the concrete form of our analogical concepts, not in autonomous metaphysics, but in God’s own self-presentation in Scripture, applied by the Spirit, so that our analogical knowledge is not merely formal but covenantally and soteriologically situated.

Thus each locus—universals, causality, simplicity, and noetic effects—serves a distinct, logically necessary function in securing a Reformed doctrine of analogy that is neither univocal nor equivocal, but grounded in the triune God’s ontological uniqueness and self-revelation.

logic_weaknesses.question:
In reviewing your written exam essay, the automatic analysis identified the following issue under weak_spots/logic_weaknesses:

The conclusion that ‘knowledge of God is only possible through special revelation’ is stated without qualification, despite earlier acknowledgment of true revelation in creation; the logical relation between general revelation, suppression, and the possibility of any true knowledge is not carefully distinguished.

Answer as in a PhD oral exam: briefly restate the issue in your own words, then give a clear, self-contained explanation that either corrects this weakness or fills this omission, from a classic Reformed confessional standpoint.
logic_weaknesses.answer_markdown:
## Restatement of the issue

The weakness lies in an unqualified claim that “knowledge of God is only possible through special revelation,” which, taken strictly, contradicts the earlier affirmation that God is truly revealed in creation. The relation between:

- the reality and clarity of general revelation,
- the noetic effects of sin and the suppression of truth,
- and the residual possibility of true, though non-saving, knowledge of God

was not carefully distinguished.

## Doctrinal clarification: revelation and knowledge

Classic Reformed theology makes several necessary distinctions.

First, **revelation and knowledge are not identical.**

- **Revelation** is God’s act of making himself and his will known, outwardly and objectively.
- **Knowledge** is the creature’s successful, Spirit-enabled reception, interpretation, and assent to that revelation.

One can therefore affirm **full reality and clarity of revelation** while also affirming **failure, distortion, or rebellion on the side of human knowing**.

Second, the Reformed tradition distinguishes **two modes of revelation**:

- **General revelation**: God’s self-disclosure in creation, providence, and conscience.
- **Special revelation**: God’s redemptive self-disclosure in Christ, inscripturated in Scripture.

Both are genuinely divine revelation; they differ not in truthfulness but in **content, scope, and soteric efficacy**.

## General revelation and true knowledge

According to classic Reformed confessions, general revelation:

- Is **clear and inescapable** with respect to God’s eternal power and divine nature.
- Truly manifests God as Creator, Lord, and Judge.
- Grounds universal responsibility and inexcusability.

Hence, it is inadequate to say that “knowledge of God is only possible through special revelation” without qualification. More precisely:

- **There is real, objective, non-saving knowledge of God that all humans have from general revelation.**
- This knowledge is sufficient to render them guilty and inexcusable.
- It is, however, neither covenant-keeping nor doxologically obedient; it is cognitively true but ethically perverted.

The language of “suppression” describes an **ethical and volitional posture** toward that knowledge, not its absence. Fallen humans:

- Know God, but refuse to glorify and thank him as God.
- Exchange the truth of God for a lie at the level of worship and worldview.
- Distort, misinterpret, and reframe the content of revelation within an idolatrous framework.

So, there is **inescapable knowledge of God from general revelation**, but it is always, apart from grace, in the mode of **rebellious and culpable knowledge**.

## Special revelation and saving knowledge

Special revelation is required not for the bare fact of knowing that God exists and is powerful and righteous, but for:

- **The knowledge of God as Redeemer in Christ**.
- **The right interpretation of general revelation** within the covenantal and redemptive-historical context.
- **Saving, filial knowledge** that trusts, loves, and worships God rightly.

Thus, in a stricter and confessional sense, what is “only possible by special revelation” is:

- The knowledge of the gospel and of God’s gracious will in Christ.
- The restoration of the entire noetic framework such that creation, conscience, and history are perceived as they truly are: the theater of God’s glory in Christ.
- The transformation of rebellious knowledge into obedient, humble, analogical knowledge that “thinks God’s thoughts after him.”

Coupled with this, the internal work of the Spirit is necessary for **saving, personal appropriation** even of special revelation. The Spirit does not supplement an otherwise deficient revelation but renovates a deficient knower.

## Integrating the pieces: corrected formulation

From a classic Reformed standpoint, the more careful statement would be:

- **General revelation** truly and clearly reveals God to all people and results in true, though always suppressed and misused, knowledge of God as Creator and Judge.
- **Special revelation**, inscripturated in Scripture and centered in Christ, is necessary for the knowledge of God as Redeemer and for the redemptive reinterpretation of general revelation.
- **The Holy Spirit** is necessary for saving knowledge: he illumines the mind and renews the heart so that both general and special revelation are received in faith, leading to right worship.

In sum, general revelation yields real but condemned knowledge of God as Creator, whereas only special revelation, received by the Spirit in faith, yields true and saving knowledge of God as Redeemer.
